description.narrative:
Estimates tell that two million people died because of the genodicidal policies of the Khmer Rouge regime between the years 1975 and 1979. Yet others were victims of tremendous sufferings caused by forced evacuations, forced labour, torture and rape. Besides the Vietnameese supported trial of 1979, which sentenced the leading cadre of the Khmer Rouge to death for their crimes and primarily had a political function, Cambodia was not able to hold own trials in accordance with international standards.
To avoid impunity and provide justice to millions of victims of the Khmer Rouge regime the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia (ECCC) was established in 2003 through a bilateral agreement between the UN and the Cambodian government. The agreement was approved by the UN General Assembly in resolution 57/228B on 13 May 2003. Cambodia adopted a national law on the Establishment of the ECCC in October 2004.
The Court began its operations in 2006. The first case, case 001, against Kaing Guek Eav, also known as "Duch", has already been concluded and the second part-case against Khieu Samphan and Nuon Chea, case 002/01, will reach a verdict in early August 2014. Further part cases against Khieu and Nuon and possibly new prosecutions awaits.
However, the court is not merely to be seen as functioning only to prosecute Khmer Rouge perpetrators. It is in many ways to be regarded as an beacon for Cambodian rule of law. A succesful implementation of the ECCC could thus have many beneficial effects for Cambodia's national courts by spreading experiences and examples of best practices into the justice system. A failure of the court, e.g. caused by lack of funding, would likewise be greatly detrimental to Cambodia's development into a modern "Rechtsstaat" (Eng. "State of Law") and would likely reflect negatively on the respective donors as well.
The thematic priorities and crosscutting issues of democracy and human rights, conflict and anticorruption are the most relevant in the planned support to ECCC and all three of them are integrated well in the ECCC's mandate and in the agreement between the Cambodian government and the UN.

Röda khmertribunalen (the Extraordinary Chambers in the Courts of Cambodia, ECCC) påbörjade sin verksamhet 2006 efter överenskommelse mellan FN och Kambodjas regering. Det huvudsakliga syftet med domstolen är att lagföra seniora röda khmerledare för brott mot nationell och internationell lagstiftning under perioden för Demokratiska Kampuchea mellan åren 1975 till 1979. De samlade brotten inbegriper bland annat ansvaret för två miljoner människors död. Domstolen är central för att framhäva vikten av lagstyre samt för övriga processer om försoning, lag och rätt i Kambodja. Flertalet NGO:er och enskilda personer kan, med ECCC som utgångspunkt, driva frågor som i vid bemärkelse relaterar till domstolens arbete. Enbart genom sin existens har domstolen därmed hjälpt till att lyfta en rad frågor om Röda khmerernas tid vid makten och det lidande de orsakade till allmän diskussion.
Domstolen är ett internationellt åtagande till vilket Sverige tidigare lämnat stöd. Hittills har ECCC åtalat och lagfört ett första fall. I ett ytterligare delfall genomfördes slutpläderingar i oktober 2013 och domar förväntas förkunnas i augusti 2014. Domstolen har nu börjat förbereda inför delfall 002/02 och ytterligare fall 003 och 004 kan komma i fråga.
Det svenska stödet avser bidrag för åren 2014 och 2015 och är av stor vikt för domstolens möjlighet att slutföra fall 002/01 samt fortsätta fall 002/02.

description.narrative: General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2015Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: During the reporting period, ECCC has continued to carry out its mandate without disruptions. Case 002 are currently handled in due order despite the death of Ieng Thirith, accused in case 002, in August 2015. Case 002/01 was appealed by the defence and Case 002/02 is ongoing. Likewise, investigations in Case 003 and 004 have been initiated. The Court is continuing to carry out its mandate in accordance to best international practise. During the reporing period, ECCC continued to spread information about its work and Court cases to the public. The efforts to transfer experiences made from ECCC into the national Court system have continued.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
